docs.lead_paragraph: Until this month, Dennis Sweeney was the only killer in New York State who was required by law to go twice a month to a mental hospital for a six-hour sleepover. Around midnight, he drove to a state hospital in Middletown, N.Y., said hello to the duty nurse and picked out an empty bed on the third floor. He woke himself at dawn, walked out of the hospital and returned to the carefully calculated anonymity of his small-town life.

headline.main: LEGALLY INSANE/A special report.; Voices in His Head Muted, A Killer Rejoins the World

docs.abstract: Special report, Legally Insane, on release of Dennis Sweeney, who murdered former congressman Allard K Lowenstein in 1980 but was found not guilty by reason of insanity and sent to New York State mental institution; examines aspects of case, notably wholesale changes in use of insanity defense in US court cases since Lowenstein's murder; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In what would be one of the biggest strikes in a decade, 85,000 telephone workers on the East Coast are threatening to walk out next weekend in a struggle that, stripped to its essentials, pits old-line labor against the New Economy. The telephone workers, who belong to the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, are facing off with Verizon Communications -- the company formed when Bell Atlantic acquired GTE last month -- largely because they fear that the company's widespread use of lower paid, nonunion workers in its fastest growing businesses, most notably wireless phones, will endanger the wages and benefits of unionized workers.

headline.main: Phone Workers Fight for Place In Wireless Era

docs.abstract: Phone Workers Fight for Place In Wireless Era** 85,000 telephone workers on East Coast are threatening walkout in struggle that pits old-line labor against New Economy; Communications Workers of America and International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers are in face-off with Verizon Communications, company formed by merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE, largely out of fear that company's widespread use of lower paid, nonunion workers in its fast growing businesses, most notably wireless phones, will endanger wages and benefits of unionized workers; stakes are high since Verizon, with 260,000 employees, has far more workers than any other American telecommunications company and is nation's largest wireless company; almost 80 percent of 120,000 workers in its local telephone division are unionized, compared with mere 46 of 32,000 in its wireless division; likely effects of strike on businesses and households from Maine to Virginia and company's efforts to prepare for it discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK BRONX: ROBBERY TURNS FATAL A man fell to his death from a seventh-story window yesterday after two men robbed his apartment and pushed him out, the police said. The robbers forced their way into the man's apartment, at the Gun Hill Houses on East Gun Hill Road in the Olinville section, around 3:40 p.m., relatives who were there told the police. The robbers fled after pushing the man out the window, said Detective Edward Reuss, a police spokesman. The victim, a man in his 40's whose name was not released pending notification of his family, landed in an outdoor stairway in front of the building and was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said they did not know what was taken from the apartment. Andy Newman (NYT) QUEENS: MEN ROBBED A band of robbers forced two men from a car in front of a Queens house yesterday and stole jewelry from them at gunpoint before spraying them with pepper gas and fleeing with the car, the police said. The authorities said the victims, Ilan Waserman, who works at a wholesale jewelry company, and his friend Yo Tall were sitting in Mr. Tall's Toyota Camry in front of Mr. Waserman's home on Daniels Street about 1:30 a.m. when at least three robbers arrived in two cars and ordered the men out. The robbers took $125,000 in jewelry, the police said. There were no arrests in the case. C. J. Chivers (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dick Cheney, the Republican choice for vice president, arrived here on the eve of the party's national convention after trying in several television interviews this morning to smooth the more conservative edges of his House voting record. In interviews on the Sunday morning talk programs, Mr. Cheney called some of the Democratic criticism of his votes ''trivial'' and ''irrelevant to the important issues of the day.'' But while he defended some of his actions, like his vote in 1986 against freedom for Nelson Mandela, he seemed to back away from his votes opposing action against ''cop-killer'' bullets and plastic guns.

headline.main: In Philadelphia, 2,000 Delegates Await the Arrival of the Star of the Republican Show

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Estimate of Ousters by H.M.O.'s Is Raised'' (news article, July 25): The withdrawal of health maintenance organizations from Medicare shows that the claim that managed care plans save money does not hold true. Medicare pays H.M.O.'s an average of 95 percent of traditional Medicare costs, and yet the H.M.O.'s assert that they cannot break even on this. If there are no savings, why should anyone give up the ability to choose a doctor and get the care the doctor prescribes, not what the insurance company decides it will provide?
docs.abstract: Herbert Semmel letter holds withdrawal of health maintenance organizations from Medicare refutes claim that managed care plans save money; calls for affordable Medicare prescription-drug coverage

docs.lead_paragraph: Trying to portray her opponent in the Senate race as out of touch with mainstream voters, Hillary Rodham Clinton described Representative Rick A. Lazio yesterday as beholden to the pharmaceutical industry for taking contributions from drug makers and voting against a bill to subsidize prescription drugs for the elderly. Speaking to reporters yesterday afternoon in the courtyard of the Municipal Building, Mrs. Clinton voiced her support for the Democrats' prescription-drug bill. She reiterated her own proposal to legalize the importing of medicine from abroad, where drugs are frequently cheaper.

headline.main: Mrs. Clinton Cites Lazio's Drug Industry Ties

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party released a television advertisement yesterday that criticizes the conservative legislative record of Dick Cheney, the Republicans' presumed vice-presidential nominee. The Democratic message is that Mr. Cheney's votes as a member of Congress from Wyoming in the 1980's are inconsistent with Gov. George W. Bush's promise of ''compassionate conservatism.'' The commercial is scheduled to be broadcast beginning Monday in 17 battleground states.

docs.lead_paragraph: FROM Washington, it seems odd that Senator Robert G. Torricelli would want to be governor of New Jersey. ''He had really begun to build himself a power base in Washington,'' observed Norman Ornstein of American Enterprise Institute, who has analyzed politicians' behavior for years. ''I'm still trying to get my arms around it.''

headline.main: Call It 'Ayatollah' or 'Caesar,' It's the Imperial Governorship; When Comparing Power, New Jersey's Chief Executive, Unlike Peers in the Other States, Holds All the Cards

docs.abstract: Article on immense power Gov Christine Todd Whitman wields as New Jersey's only elected state official; former Gov Thomas Kean asserts that governor in New Jersey is very important, noting attention is already focused on 2001 election; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sheelah Anne Morrissey, a daughter of Elizabeth T. Morrissey and Kevin E. Morrissey of Manhasset, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Joseph Gerard Quinn, a son of Sharon M. Quinn and William J. Quinn of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Matthew A. Quinn performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Quinn, who will continue to use her maiden name professionally, is a senior account executive in the Norwalk, Conn., sales office of R. R. Donnelley & Sons, the printing company. She graduated from Iona College. Her father owns an insurance agency in Woodside, Queens.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Sister Mary Vincent Sharp got the call that there was some free furniture at a house in Northeast Philadelphia, she had to get there. When no one else was available to make the run over there during the Memorial Day weekend, the 74-year-old nun took her aging Ford Econoline truck into Philadelphia because she knew there were families here who could use the tables and chairs.

headline.main: For 25 Years, a Point of Light

docs.abstract: Profile of Sister Mary Vincent Sharp, who has spent last 25 years working at Catholic Social Services offices in Camden, NJ, connecting needy people with wide variety of donated items; photo (M)
